description: Fundamentals of Statistics. Descriptive statistics and simple linear regression. Emphasis is on the development of statistical thinking and applications are directed towards the behavioral sciences, especially psychology, and medicine. Topics include probability, statistical inference, hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.
name: LECTURE

values.comments:
STAT111 is an introductory statistics course intended for students in the College, as opposed to the more business-oriented STAT101. Methods of statistical analysis are taught with an eye towards the behavioral sciences, and example data sets are pulled from psychology and medicine. Topics include probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, and regression. The course requires high school algebra as background knowledge, using JMP software for more complicated calculations.

A majority of reviewing students praised the course as enjoyable and relevant. A couple of reviewers disliked the textbook; some found its informal style to statistics confusing and out-of-sync with standard statistical formulae. Some students were frustrated at the lack of a detailed syllabus and course schedule, which hindered advance planning. One student grumbled that the statistics project was announced unexpectedly and without a clear grading scheme.
Most students said Professor Wyner was a great lecturer. One called him “one of the best lecturers I’ve ever had at Penn.” Many approved of his “engaging,” “stimulating,” and “enthusiastic” approach to making statistics relevant, which emphasized concepts and real-world examples. While students frequently commented that his teaching style is “dynamic” and “entertaining,” a few students thought it was too indirect and didn’t highlight core equations or concepts. One student wrote, “His classes seem to mirror what’s in the textbook almost exactly, and I sometimes wonder if there is any point in going to the lecture if you read the textbook.”

STAT 111 is intended to be a College student’s introduction to statistics. Homework was abundant, but counted for only 20% of the final grade. A few students complained that exams did not reflect what was taught in class. Students with a more advanced mathematical background felt bored and did not feel like they learned very much from the class.

Methods of statistical analysis are taught with an eye towards the behavioral sciences, and example data sets are pulled from psychology and medicine. Topics include probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, and regression. The course requires high school algebra as background knowledge, using JMP software for more complicated calculations.

A majority of reviewing students praised the course as enjoyable and relevant. A couple of reviewers disliked the textbook; some found its informal style to statistics confusing and out-of-sync with standard statistical formulae. Some students were frustrated at the lack of a detailed syllabus and course schedule, which hindered advance planning. One student grumbled that the statistics project was announced unexpectedly and without a clear grading scheme.
Most students said Professor Wyner was a great lecturer. One called him “one of the best lecturers I’ve ever had at Penn.” Many approved of his “engaging,” “stimulating,” and “enthusiastic” approach to making statistics relevant, which emphasized concepts and real-world examples. While students frequently commented that his teaching style is “dynamic” and “entertaining,” a few students thought it was too indirect and didn’t highlight core equations or concepts. One student wrote, “His classes seem to mirror what’s in the textbook almost exactly, and I sometimes wonder if there is any point in going to the lecture if you read the textbook.”

STAT 111 is intended to be a College student’s introduction to statistics. Homework was abundant, but counted for only 20% of the final grade. A few students complained that exams did not reflect what was taught in class. Students with a more advanced mathematical background felt bored and did not feel like they learned very much from the class.

This is the recitation section led by the teaching assistant Sathyanarayan Anand for Introduction to Statistics (Stat111). Statistics 111 covers the basics from probability to regression to hypothesis testing. The data analysis and statistical methods taught will be useful in its application to the social sciences, and the course will introduce students to JMP software.
There was a significant difference in the numerical scores that section 202 gave compared to section 203. Students in the 202 section gave the course an overall better score than the students from section 203. Most students in both sections agreed that the Anand was not the best person to stimulate student interest.

Students overall found Anand “knowledgeable,” but quite a few seemed to feel this was hindered by his “distractingly strong” accent. Those who could understand him really enjoyed recitation and “learned a lot.” However, quite a few complained that he moved too “fast” during the recitation, and many felt he could have involved the class more in his recitation.

This course fulfills the Formal Reasoning and Analysis requirement of the University, and is also a prerequisite in many majors like Psychology. It assumes mastery of high school algebra. It is recommended for majors and non-majors.
